title: The Best Energy Stock Today. Hands Down!

transcript.text:
Would you believe that the world's third-largest 
oil reserve is just a bunch of sand soaked oil?

And this now represents the cheapest way to 
extract oil from the earth. Sounds crazy,

right? Today, we're going to discuss one of the 
most interesting energy plays I've ever seen

that nobody's talking about. And we'll tell you 
exactly which stock is the best investment to get

exposure to this theme. It also happens to be one 
of our highest-ranked dividend growth stocks. So,

let's start with some interesting facts. Look at 
this list of countries with the largest proven

oil reserves. Ever wonder why the Americans 
like to spread freedom in places like Iraq,

Libya, and Kuwait? Well, now you know. Not a lot 
of friendly faces on this list, right? Venezuela's

been uttering a lot of fighting words lately. 
They're the country with the largest proven oil

reserves. Same for Russia and Iran. Now, perhaps 
the friendliest face on this list would be Canada.

Reminds me of that old joke. You know how to get 
a 100 drunk Canadians out of your bar? You ask

them to leave. Canadians are known for being 
friendly. Now, these friendly Canadians have

nearly five times the amount of oil reserves 
that the Americans do. And the Americans just

happen to be the largest consumers of oil. 20% 
of the world's oil, followed by China at 13%,

and then it dramatically drops off from there. 
Now, what's rather interesting is that the Saudis

are so high on this list, and that's because they 
use oil to generate electricity. Now, I always

thought of the Saudis as sort of the leading 
producer of oil and the leading exporter of

oil to the United States. Well, that's not true at 
all. This is really incredible if you think about

it. The United States now produces more crude 
oil than any country ever. However, it consumes

more crude than it produces. So, therefore, it 
remains a net importer of oil. And when we look

at the countries that the US imports from, again, 
a rather interesting factoid here. Look at the top

three names here. The US imports the majority of 
its oil from Canada, followed by 11% from Mexico.

Rather surprising. Then you have the Saudis 
at 5%. So over half of all the US's petroleum

imports come from Canada. So let's summarize. 
The Americans use more crude oil than anyone

else and also produce more crude oil than anyone 
else. However, they still need to import crude,

and over half of those imports come from Canada. 
Canada's a country with the world's third-largest

proven reserves and a favorable geopolitical 
climate. And this is remarkable: Canadian firms

are now producing oil at a cheaper cost than all 
other oil majors. How is this possible? Well,

it all comes down to oil sands. Now, back in 
my business school days, we had some BSD come

in and teach the class about how to navigate 
the interview process. And he asked everyone,

"Can somebody pitch me a stock?" So, I pitched 
him Canadian oil sands. That's because back then,

my highest conviction thesis was peak oil. Now, 
that's not necessarily that we're running out of

oil. It's just that all the low-hanging fruit, 
the easy oil to extract is gone. So, now it's

more difficult to extract oil and more expensive. 
Thus, the price of oil ought to go up. And it

did. But not for Canada. It's actually going 
down. Check out this article from Reuters. How

Canada's oil sands transformed into one of North 
America's lowest cost plays. And you see they have

a Boston Dynamics robot here. Apparently, it's now 
conducting routine inspections and saving Imperial

Oil around $22 million a year. The article talks 
about how giant shovels, autonomous trucks,

and dog-like robots have all helped Canada's oil 
sand companies, like Imperial Oil and Suncor,

become some of North America's lowest-cost oil 
producers. And that's even as the worst inflation

in a generation has pushed US shale costs up. So, 
Canada's oil sand industry now finds itself in a

position of strength. And I think this diagram 
says it all. On the left, you have the break

even for oil sands, the five largest producers 
of oil from oil sands that are responsible for

the vast majority of that output. And on the 
right, you see the break even for US producers.

So basically oil sands around $40 a barrel, they 
can still be profitable. And for all the others,

it's more like $60 a barrel. And when you look at 
shale versus oil sands, this is quite interesting.

So oil sand producers have lowered their overall 
cost by approximately $10 a barrel in about 7

years. So for example, autonomous trucks improved 
the oil output productivity at Imperial's Curo oil

sands mine by 20% since 2023. Break even costs 
across the board have fallen from $53 to $43

for oil sand producers over a 7-year time span. 
Contrast this to shale oil producers. They need

$65 per barrel on average to profitably drill. 
Now, contrast that to 7 years ago, or so, when US

shale producers had a break even price of between 
$50 and $52 per barrel. So, they're moving in the

wrong direction. Shale's getting more expensive. 
Oil sands are getting cheaper. And I found this

incredible. The US actually has the largest known 
deposits of shale oil in the world. Something like

2 trillion barrels worth. Rather remarkable. 
And, consequently, about 64% of total US crude

oil production in 2023 came from shale. Now when 
we look at the oil reserves in Canada, they're

estimated at around 172 billion barrels. Of those, 
95% are in the oil sands deposit in the province

of Alberta. So if you consider Alberta and the 
oil sands and the other oil that it has, then

Alberta's share of the oil reserves in Canada is 
somewhere around 98%. Remarkable. Right? Now, just

a little bit more about oil sands. There's really 
two ways to extract oil from oil sands. First,

you have mining, and that's when the oil's very 
close to the surface. Essentially, they scrape up,

I think it's two tons of sand per barrel of oil. 
These huge volumes of sand and clay are then

filtered out so that you just have the oil left. 
And when the oil's deeper in the ground, these

companies inject steam to loosen the deposits 
and then use a drilling process. So an oil sands

mine typically has big initial startup costs, 
but once it's operational, can run for decades

with very low production decline rates. Now, I 
acknowledge there's an environmental conversation,

a rather big one to be had, but we're not going 
to have that today. Now when we look at investing

in this thesis, I asked Gemini and it pointed to 
the big three. So major producers in the Alberta

oil sands are Canadian Natural Resources, Suncor, 
and Senovas. And then they also mention two other

names, Imperial Oil and MEG Energy. And they say 
that Alberta's total oil sands production around

3.5 million barrels per day. And that these five 
producers make up the majority of that volume.

And of course, the question that we want to 
answer is what percentage of total revenues

would come from oil sands. In other words, if we 
want oil sands exposure, we want to make sure the

companies we're investing in primarily work in 
that area. And for the names here on the list,

you can see that there's a very high percentage 
of total revenue coming from oil sands,

according to Gemini. We can then ask this same 
question to Grok. It tells us something similar.

And basically, these top five names accounted for 
80% of Alberta's oil sands output in 2024. Now,

we're primarily interested in investing always 
in leaders. And when we look at Canadian natural

resources, which always comes to the top of these 
lists, they say around 63% of total revenues in

2024 came from their oil sands operations. You can 
see that broken down here. It's predominantly oil

sands mining. Well, they also have the drilling 
component there as well. So, both methods. And

when we look at these two types, they talk about 
their world-class oil sands mining assets having a

lower break even price than any of their other 
Canadian peers. We like that, right? Leaders

often have lower costs of goods sold because 
- economies of scale. Then we look at the cost

of their drilling operation. Again, lower than 
their peers. So the reason that Canadian natural

resources came on our radar was not because of 
oil sands. It's because it's one of a number of

foreign dividend champions. So we have a dividend 
growth investing strategy called Quantigence,

where we've taken over 200 dividend champions 
across the world and ranked them according to a

Q-score which takes into account seven factors for 
dividend growth stocks that help determine whether

or not these companies will continue to increase 
their dividends over time. As you can see here,

Canadian Natural has quite the track record. 
25 consecutive years of dividend increases. So,

it's a formal champion and that dividend has 
grown by 21% compound annual growth rate since

inception. That's rather remarkable. It's one 
of the reasons why it has such a high Q-score.

And just a side note here, we always make sure to 
exclude special dividends when we're considering

the dividend track record of any given company. So 
when we go to our dividend growth universe of over

200 stocks, and we filter on energy, here you can 
see the top four energy stocks ranked. Canadian

Natural Resources is actually the second-highest 
ranked stock in our entire universe and also it

was interesting to note Imperial Oil on this list 
as well. So you have two dividend growth plays

here that could potentially give you exposure to 
Canadian oil sands. Now, it's very important to

note that the Canadians generally hold back 15% 
on dividends paid to non-residents. Apparently,

you can claim some foreign tax credit for 
Americans, but that's really up to you to

figure out. Taxation becomes very complicated 
in a hurry. But from both the oil sands thesis

perspective and a dividend growth perspective, 
we find Canadian Natural Resources to be quite

attractive. And we may look to do a future piece 
on oil sands companies and/or Canadian Resources.

We're running out of time today. So just to 
conclude, we're just one missile launched in the

Strait of Hormuz away from oil prices spiking. Now 
Canada has the most reserves for the least amount

of geopolitical risk, and they also produce 
oil cheaper than anyone else. These numbers

are continuing to decline thanks to technologies 
like robotics and autonomy. And for some reason,

oil sands just aren't on the radar of most 
investors. Maybe they should be. Now, Canadian

Natural Resources stands on its own as one of the 
best dividend growth stocks out there. And it's a

great way to play the oil sand story. Now, when it 
comes to high-performing energy stocks, one stock

out there takes the cake. The highest performing 
energy stock of all time. It's one we happen to

be holding. Give this video a watch next. Thanks 
so much for taking the time to watch this today.
